displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So they don’t want to, uh, subject you to, you know, have a needle stuck in your bone if it’s not going to be helpful. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so, but the trial requires the tissue, because they’re trying to study how the new drug affects the tissue in some way. So let me, let me look into that, uh, to see if any of the trials allow bone only. The only trials we have for hormonal treatment are with Xtandi right now, uh, not with the other drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, if it looks like you can’t, if it looks like you would fit on the trial, we can talk about them more. If, if it looks like the bone thing is going to eliminate that- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Then I would just proceed with the Xtandi and start it. Okay? (Sound Door closes) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The other piece of this that’s an unknown piece is, we have some sets that the people who got testosterone, even the ones that didn’t respond to it, seemed to have a better response to drugs like Xtandi or Zytiga afterwards. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And our, our idea is maybe that the cells have gotten used to being low testosterone and they’ve kind of adjusted. Then we put them in high testosterone, they adjust to that-

Patient: And I go back I think it’s in March. He gave me a six month shot this time. Doctor: Perfect. So, we will do the scans. I will see you back after you do the scan so it might be a week or two tops and then we’ll have a plan. In the meantime, I will have J____ start looking at your Provenge insurance so that we either know yes or no. We just need to know that, Patient: Okay. Doctor: okay, and then we’ll chat about what we see and we’ll get a plan. You’ve heard the kitchen sink now. Now we just have to pick one. Alright, I’ve got to make sure nobody else needs you for anything. Thank you Patient: Alright, thank you. Doctor: as always. Let me know about that leg too. Patient: Yeah. I got to say this only happened probably all that driving. Doctor: Yeah. If that’s no better, we need to know. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Oh hi, Come on in. Healthcare Professional: Hello. Patient: How are you doing? Doctor: We chatted about all sorts of things.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 3 years (2 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 3 years (2 years but less than 3 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: What was the guy at O____ there that we saw? Patient: ____ was the first one. Doctor: Oh Dr. _____, okay, yeah. So all the others - Patient: And then he sent me to - Doctor: Yeah, here we are, right. Family Member: So all the other tests that he’s had- Doctor: Mm, hmm. Family Member: — the ultrasound, all that stuff, the x-ray, I mean everything’s good? Doctor: Okay, I mean good in the sense there’s nothing to do other than change the treatment and move on to the next level. Family Member: It hasn’t spread to anything else. Doctor: Nothing else. I mean it’s just bone. Family Member: Right.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And if it’s time we do it. You know? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If it’s like absolutely the same, then we’re just going to hang out. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, kind of play around with pills and see if we can get it down. Family Member: Oh, okay. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I need to be assured as you guys do also. Family Member: Right. Doctor: That there’s nothing new or that these guys all of a sudden didn’t wake up and go, yeah, well, we were sleeping. Family Member: Right. Doctor: All those lymph nodes and now we’re awake. And we would know if we’re awake because it would be bigger or if it was new. Like, wait a minute.

Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. (Pause10sec) Patient: No. Doctor: Heart failure? Patient: No. Doctor: Any issues with – did you ever have a blood transfusion? Patient: I had a little stroke – I had a little stroke a couple years ago. Doctor: Okay. We have that. Did you ever have a seizure? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Any problem with your thyroid gland? Patient: No. Doctor: Sleep apnea?

Family Member: Sure. Um hum. We can put off the cataract surgery, too. Doctor: Yeah. If he had to. Family Member: But it’s hard to get. Doctor: But for now let’s keep it. Family Member: That’s what I think. We’ve waited a long time. Doctor: Don’t, don’t change anything until we see what the dates fall out to be. Family Member: Fine. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if we have to, we really have to, we will, but I’m going to try and work around these dates. Okay? Patient: Why don’t you let me sign it now so I don’t have to come back? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I’m going to have S___ come in and so she can bring the consent in. Okay? Patient: How’s your husband? Doctor: He’s doing well. Thanks for asking. (Laughter)

Patient: Cancer. The cancer subsided or it can't reverse cancer get worse. Doctor: The cancer has gotten worse and moved on to new spots or new areas. Oh, you know, it's not gonna be shy. It'll tell us. Yeah. So at this moment is just sort of the slow creep, you know, it’s the- What do you mean? It's six right? I mean, you haven't way in the beginning you were near 300 there but you've always been super low. So when we look at you, it's like this tiny little rises but nothing that's like this. Yeah, Patient: Just a quick note- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - it started out much higher than that. I think you get Doctor: Yeah, no, no, I had you correct. Yeah, we met each other after your stuff started but in our system, that's as high as you been? Patient: Yeah.This may not be a question for you. But if I were to retire- Doctor: Mhm. Patient: I'm not sure. I'm not sure what kind of health care insurance I'm gonna have. Doctor: Okay, yeah. Patient: Yeah, but, is so I don't know have you- I don’t know how to ask the question. So is there assistance available? If I would need it if I changed to a different insurance. Doctor: You mean as per trial or in general

Patient: I know. Doctor: I think we talked about the chiropractor and when you have stuff in your back it’s probably not the most stable. Patient: I know, I know. Doctor: However, I think this is enough of a signal that that area in the back tells me that it’s a little bit something more than it was. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: That’s the first. The second part is sort of the rest of you and I know W__ wanted to share that too Patient: Yeah. Doctor: of just the stuff. Healthcare Professional: Oh yeah. There’s you know some other areas some lymph nodes are slightly enlarged, Patient: Right. Doctor: they’ve gotten a little bit bigger. Your PSA has gone up just a little bit too. So I think… Patient: What’s a little bit? Healthcare Professional: Your last one was thirty one point seven a week ago it was twenty six.

Patient: I can’t talk. Like somebody’s stoppin’ and be talkin’ to me. But, let’s go walk up so ‘cuz I can’t stand up that long. Doctor: I see. Patient: And, also, I’ll be out of breath and then my legs Doctor: Yeah, Okay. Patient: get weak. I can, um, I’m all for the standing and talk, bro, that we are gonna talk, let’s sit down. Doctor: So, what do you want to do? Do you want to take a break from the chemotherapy? Patient: Um, it’s up to you, dear. What’s your take, doctor? I think it, it’s Doctor: It’s been working very well against your cancer… Patient: Okay. And they had my blood tests came back? Doctor: Your PSA’s not back from today, but last time, it was continuing to go down. Patient: What was it? What was it? Doctor: Your PSA was one seventy-three..

Patient: Okay. (Pause4sec) Patient: It’s just what I do to deal with the cancer. Doctor: Chew gum. Patient: Okay. Can’t stand it. Doctor: Hmmm? Patient: Oh, I hope my teeth can stand it. (sighs) Doctor: Okay. So we saw you the beginning of April. How you feeling? Patient: Okay. Uh, I guess about five o’clock in the afternoon, uh I run out of gas. Doctor: Uh, runs out of gas. Uh, so, what does that mean? You have to take a nap or you just -- ? Patient: I have to, I have to sit. I did mow the grass, but, um, it gets. Patient: Nope. I don’t do much at all. Doctor: And what are you missin’ out on?

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So you’re going after them just because you can see it but there is no guarantee that what we can see on the CAT scan is the only place at this point in time where the cancer is at. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: So we might graph that lymph node and your PSA might drop by fifteen percent, then we’ll know in retrospect had we got that lymph node we might have actually killed all of the cells in that lymph node - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and yet your PSA might drop by fifteen or twenty-five percent. And so what we’ve learnt the hard way, so-to-speak with experience, is that although we can do that, it is technically feasible -um and there are some types of radiation that can be reimbursed by insurance companies, for example - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - um we have not seen cases where that is curative. That is also another type of therapy that delays the progression of the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So so for example, if your primary goal was to delay hormone therapy for as long as possible, like if you really wanted at all cost to avoid hormone therapy - Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the one thing that we could consider would be referring you to a radiation oncologist that specializes in the type of radiation called stereotactic radio therapy, which is a very sort of focused -

Patient: Why wouldn’t we go site specific in all the other areas that I have- Family Member: You don’t want too much. Too much will kill ya’. Patient: -that you have imaging to know where it is? Doctor: Well, because it doesn’t change the outcome. So your treatment is so that the pain gets better as in kill the cells, no pain. If you have pain elsewhere, you could consider that. But if it’s just a pluck off the areas that you think has cancer, it doesn’t change the overall status of your disease. You know? You don’t live longer with it but you might get some down sides. You know? Like she said the more you radiate the more your bone marrow is hit. So you’ll get a consequence off of that where you might lose some cells. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So you don’t want to treat them unless you know what you’re going to get a result of. So with radiation right now the result is gee I hope my pain is controlled. That’s what I wanted for you. The second one would be gee I hope my pain is controlled and my spine gets stabilized. Whew. And then number three would be I hope the cancer doesn’t come back there. You know? Now it’s been burned out. Family Member: Uh Huh. Doctor: I don’t want that sort of trouble. Okay? Family Member: Are, are Have they come, - Is there any chance that they’d come closer to a purification, cure for cancer? Like that chelation therapy that I heard about years ago. Is that something that the insurance companies are willing to look at? Doctor: Hum. No. Nothing, nothing close to primetime yet. Family Member: But it is a, it is an effective treatment, right? Doctor: I’m not sure exactly.

Patient: No. I’m not freaked out. Doctor: You’re our movie star today. (door closes) Patient: No. Not at all. This this comes from… Doctor: How are ya. Patient: I am good. How are you? Doctor: Good, not too bad. Patient: Did you get your certificate? Doctor: My certificate? Patient: From the U_______. Doctor: I did! How did you know that? (pause) Patient: I – You you want me to be the best patient you’ve got, I… Patient: I have to know all that stuff. Doctor: Thank you. I’m now officially the Rudi Ansbacher academic scholar at U______.

Family Member 2: Right, right. Doctor: I mean then I think we should sort of say I don’t care what the PSA is doing but you’re doing great and the scans are looking fine. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We just stay the course. Questions? Family Member: I just have one question. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: So from part one to part two the trial that he was on, Doctor: Mm Hmm Family Member: was there any statistics showing promise from part one to part two or was it…? Doctor: In this particular one? These pills that he’s on? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: The part two hasn’t started yet. So right now he’s is on the phase one but we know what dose to give him so… Family Member: Right, the part two – part one of this phase one series.

Patient: - I see him. Doctor: I’m sure he’s going to be happy with your progress, but we’ll see. Again, if you see him then, and you’re like, ah, not better, hello, he can order the MRI. Family Member: Yeah. He’s been taking the Norco and stuff where before he wasn’t taking that. Doctor: How’s the rest of you? Family Member: Tired. Patient: Yeah. Sleep, sleep is a- Doctor: Listen. Your blood sugar is dismal. Let’s just talk about tired and a blood sugar of three eighty five. Family Member: Will make you tired. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Family Member: Well, you’ve got one there. Doctor: Huh? Oh, yeah. Family Member: I know I get, I know I get, I’m tired when mine’s high. Sometimes I had a two, and I cut out all sorts of carbs, all carbs basically.
